Home Anime Attack on Titan: What Is an Ackerman, Anyway?    Attack on Titan: What Is an Ackerman, Anyway?  By Marc York Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Here's everything there is to know about the Ackerman bloodline of Attack on Titan, including what they are and what they can do.            Ackerman Family      The following contains spoilers for Attack on Titan Season 4, Episode 28, "The Dawn of Humanity," now streaming on Funimation, Hulu and Crunchyroll.   Attack on Titan: The Final Season has brought a number of big surprises to the table, especially as they pertain to the Ackermans. Eren, in particular, had a lot to say about the clan, although he used this information to force Mikasa to hate her. He told the poor girl that her feelings for him were an instinctive part of her Ackerman blood rather than genuinely-developed feelings of affection. This, among other things Eren said, broke Mikasa's heart, but it might not have been true.  The last episode of The Final Season Part 2 reveals a different explanation from Zeke. The sum of his information suggests that Mikasa's feelings are, in fact, genuine and have nothing to do with her lineage. Eren's apparent lies have made the truth about the Ackermans hard to follow for fans. In order to clear things up, here's a look at everything there is to know about the Ackerman family. RELATED: Attack on Titan: The Final Season Part 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions                Historically, the Ackermans were meant to live in service to the Eldian royal family. However, after the fall of Eldia, they rejected King Fritz's idea of peace, so they were persecuted and hunted to near-extinction. It was only after Kenny Ackerman met Uri Reiss, then the reigning king, that the purge stopped.  The Ackerman family was created through experimentation by the old Eldian Empire on the Subjects of Ymir. As a result of this experimentation, the Ackermans were granted the ability to use the Power of the Titans while in human form. This is most observable in their practically-superhuman feats, including Mikasa's strength and Levi's ability to survive a point-blank Thunder Spear. RELATED: Attack on Titan: Historia's Fate Parallels Grisha'sThe Ackermans are also immune to the memory manipulation of the Founding Titan, which is how they retained their memories of life before the Walls. This is also partly the reason they were able to reject King Fritz's ideals; if they could be forced to forget, they wouldn't even know what there was to be against. This inability to be controlled is what led King Fritz to hunt them down to a handful.  Another ability of the Ackermans is to be "awakened." Besides their superhuman abilities, they also gain the battle experience of previous Ackermans through the paths. This is what makes them so proficient in combat, especially Levi "Humanity's Strongest Soldier" Ackerman. The only caveat is that the Ackermans need to be awakened by their instinct to survive. Mikasa exemplified this when she was nine and Eren told her to "fight" as they were attacked by robbers. By tapping into her hidden potential, she could crush a knife grip, break floorboards, and stab a robber through the heart from behind. If her life wasn't put in danger, she would have remained an ordinary little girl.  RELATED: Attack on Titan Solves the Colossal Titans' Biggest Weakness According to Eren, however, there was another cause for this awakening. In Episode 14 of The Final Season, "Savagery," Eren said that the awakening was caused in response to an Ackerman's instinct to defend a "host." This could be seen as plausible as many of the Ackermans could also be said to have hosts; for Levi, it would have been Erwin Smith; for Kenny, there was Uri. All the Ackermans who went on to be warriors had somebody they wanted to protect. Eren further backed his claim about Ackerman instincts by citing Mikasa's headaches. According to him, the headaches are caused by the Ackermans' true personalities trying to oppose the host. He went on to say that Mikasa's inclination to follow her Ackerman blood, and thus not be free, was what made him hate her.  Later, however, Armin suggested to Mikasa that Eren might have been lying about all of this. In Episode 18, "Sneak Attack," he put forth that He and Eren had known about Mikasa's headaches for a long time. He went on to suggest that Eren used that one truth to make the rest of what he said sound convincing. For all they knew, everything else Eren said was a lie. While this uncertainty about what was and wasn't true comforted Mikasa, it was also the source of a lot of confusion among the fans. RELATED: Marco's Final Words on Attack on Titan Are the Anime's Most Important                 Thankfully, Episode 28, "The Dawn of Humanity," helped to discern fact from fiction. In a flashback, Eren was shown having a conversation with Zeke Yeager about the cause of Mikasa's devotion to him. While awakening through triggered survival instincts was confirmed to be true through research, there was no evidence that it had anything to do with headaches or a host. In Zeke's humble opinion, Mikasa's faithfulness was simply because she liked Eren. In any case, the Ackermans are an incredible family. Their strength, instinct for battle, and immunity to the Founder's powers make them a force to be reckoned with. With all that said, the cause of Mikasa's headaches remains a mystery. Home Anime Attack on Titan: What Is an Ackerman, Anyway?    Attack on Titan: What Is an Ackerman, Anyway?  By Marc York Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Here's everything there is to know about the Ackerman bloodline of Attack on Titan, including what they are and what they can do.            Ackerman Family      The following contains spoilers for Attack on Titan Season 4, Episode 28, "The Dawn of Humanity," now streaming on Funimation, Hulu and Crunchyroll.   Attack on Titan: The Final Season has brought a number of big surprises to the table, especially as they pertain to the Ackermans. Eren, in particular, had a lot to say about the clan, although he used this information to force Mikasa to hate her. He told the poor girl that her feelings for him were an instinctive part of her Ackerman blood rather than genuinely-developed feelings of affection. This, among other things Eren said, broke Mikasa's heart, but it might not have been true.  The last episode of The Final Season Part 2 reveals a different explanation from Zeke. The sum of his information suggests that Mikasa's feelings are, in fact, genuine and have nothing to do with her lineage. Eren's apparent lies have made the truth about the Ackermans hard to follow for fans. In order to clear things up, here's a look at everything there is to know about the Ackerman family. RELATED: Attack on Titan: The Final Season Part 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions                Historically, the Ackermans were meant to live in service to the Eldian royal family. However, after the fall of Eldia, they rejected King Fritz's idea of peace, so they were persecuted and hunted to near-extinction. It was only after Kenny Ackerman met Uri Reiss, then the reigning king, that the purge stopped.  The Ackerman family was created through experimentation by the old Eldian Empire on the Subjects of Ymir. As a result of this experimentation, the Ackermans were granted the ability to use the Power of the Titans while in human form. This is most observable in their practically-superhuman feats, including Mikasa's strength and Levi's ability to survive a point-blank Thunder Spear. RELATED: Attack on Titan: Historia's Fate Parallels Grisha'sThe Ackermans are also immune to the memory manipulation of the Founding Titan, which is how they retained their memories of life before the Walls. This is also partly the reason they were able to reject King Fritz's ideals; if they could be forced to forget, they wouldn't even know what there was to be against. This inability to be controlled is what led King Fritz to hunt them down to a handful.  Another ability of the Ackermans is to be "awakened." Besides their superhuman abilities, they also gain the battle experience of previous Ackermans through the paths. This is what makes them so proficient in combat, especially Levi "Humanity's Strongest Soldier" Ackerman. The only caveat is that the Ackermans need to be awakened by their instinct to survive. Mikasa exemplified this when she was nine and Eren told her to "fight" as they were attacked by robbers. By tapping into her hidden potential, she could crush a knife grip, break floorboards, and stab a robber through the heart from behind. If her life wasn't put in danger, she would have remained an ordinary little girl.  RELATED: Attack on Titan Solves the Colossal Titans' Biggest Weakness According to Eren, however, there was another cause for this awakening. In Episode 14 of The Final Season, "Savagery," Eren said that the awakening was caused in response to an Ackerman's instinct to defend a "host." This could be seen as plausible as many of the Ackermans could also be said to have hosts; for Levi, it would have been Erwin Smith; for Kenny, there was Uri. All the Ackermans who went on to be warriors had somebody they wanted to protect. Eren further backed his claim about Ackerman instincts by citing Mikasa's headaches. According to him, the headaches are caused by the Ackermans' true personalities trying to oppose the host. He went on to say that Mikasa's inclination to follow her Ackerman blood, and thus not be free, was what made him hate her.  Later, however, Armin suggested to Mikasa that Eren might have been lying about all of this. In Episode 18, "Sneak Attack," he put forth that He and Eren had known about Mikasa's headaches for a long time. He went on to suggest that Eren used that one truth to make the rest of what he said sound convincing. For all they knew, everything else Eren said was a lie. While this uncertainty about what was and wasn't true comforted Mikasa, it was also the source of a lot of confusion among the fans. RELATED: Marco's Final Words on Attack on Titan Are the Anime's Most Important                 Thankfully, Episode 28, "The Dawn of Humanity," helped to discern fact from fiction. In a flashback, Eren was shown having a conversation with Zeke Yeager about the cause of Mikasa's devotion to him. While awakening through triggered survival instincts was confirmed to be true through research, there was no evidence that it had anything to do with headaches or a host. In Zeke's humble opinion, Mikasa's faithfulness was simply because she liked Eren. In any case, the Ackermans are an incredible family. Their strength, instinct for battle, and immunity to the Founder's powers make them a force to be reckoned with. With all that said, the cause of Mikasa's headaches remains a mystery. Home Anime Sakamoto Days Feels Like It Comes From the '90s - and That's a Good Thing    Sakamoto Days Feels Like It Comes From the '90s - and That's a Good Thing  By Dallas Marshall Published 2 days ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Sakamoto Days has the feel of a manga from the '90s which may be off-putting to some, but there's more than enough hijinks and action to draw in fans.                 People who come from a history of crime have a lot to deal with. As they do their best to live a clean life, they sometimes have to deal with their former checkered lives, such as vengeful enemies, temptations to make "easy money" and old compatriots trying to force them back into their old ways. Most stories surrounding the theme of redemption and trying to escape a life of crime usually end in tragedy, a sad reminder that crime doesn't pay.  Today's manga is anything but sad, serious or a cautionary tale. Sakamoto Days, written by Yuto Suzuki and published by Viz Media, is a silly romp surrounding the life of a former hitman named Sakamoto. He was not just any hitman but the greatest the Yakuza have ever seen. Sakamoto was dashing, deadly and an expert killer. But after starting a family, he is now out of shape and the only trigger he pulls is the one on a bar code scanner since, after leaving his life of crime, he opened a convenience store with his lovely wife and child. While he may have left the underworld behind him, the underworld has not forgotten Sakamoto. A figure from his past comes to his store and makes a request: "return to the assassin world, or die!"  RELATED: The Director of Escaflowne Was Also Behind This Old-School Sci-Fi Crime Anim                The first noticeable factor about Sakamoto Days is that the art style is reminiscent of Viz Media's 1990s manga. The linework is softer and has less of the in-your-face aesthetics that cover the pages of modern-day manga. Sakamoto Days is a crime story that feels less like the gritty work of such dramas as Gangsta or Black Lagoon and more like a '90s staple such as Fushigi Yugi or Yu Yu Hakusho. While this may be off-putting to some fans of modern manga, the juxtaposition of softness mixed with the plot's challenging crime themes is an amusing dualism.  It is also funny that the jokes are thrown at the reader at a mile-a-minute pace alongside the action, which usually involves Sakamoto dealing with the day-to-day struggles of life like going to the grocery store is as severe as an assassination mission. After all, old habits die hard. However, despite its comedic tones, Sakamoto Days is for an older teen audience and features some violent scenes that should be avoided by the younger readers in the crowd. Luckily for our out-of-shape former criminal, he has a loving family that helps him keep on the straight and narrow. One of the best things about this manga is its main lead characters. Sakamoto's wife, Aoi, is his rock throughout and while she does know of his dark past, she sees the good in him and makes it her life's mission to guide her husband to be the best man he can be.  RELATED: The Best Free Short Manga on Manga Plus                 Love can change a man and Sakamoto Days reminds readers that even those who have the shadiest of histories can find redemption. So, instead of being a hitman for the Yakuza, Sakamoto utilizes his quick reflexes for customer care and community service, even if he gets carried away at times -- much to the chagrin of his wife and readers' amusement. As for some of the secondary characters in this manga, such as fellow former assassin-turned-convenience-store-clerk Shin, not many unique traits can be spoken for. Most of the side characters are, for lack of a better term, just there.  Sakamoto Days does not reinvent the wheel when it comes to comedy manga. The jokes are serviceable, complete with slapstick humor and visual gags that induce chuckles. The action scenes are well put together but will not blow readers' minds. But as a fun diversion with a somewhat retro aesthetic, Sakamoto Days does not need to be revolutionary to be entertaining and sets out to tell a silly story about redemption. It's the white cake of comedy manga: simple, somewhat sweet and direct. In a challenging world such as ours, sometimes folks need some comfort food -- even if it's all about crime and the bloodshed that comes with it. While he may have left the underworld behind him, the underworld has not forgotten Sakamoto. A figure from his past comes to his store and makes a request: "return to the assassin world, or die!"  RELATED: The Director of Escaflowne Was Also Behind This Old-School Sci-Fi Crime Anim                The first noticeable factor about Sakamoto Days is that the art style is reminiscent of Viz Media's 1990s manga. The linework is softer and has less of the in-your-face aesthetics that cover the pages of modern-day manga. Sakamoto Days is a crime story that feels less like the gritty work of such dramas as Gangsta or Black Lagoon and more like a '90s staple such as Fushigi Yugi or Yu Yu Hakusho. While this may be off-putting to some fans of modern manga, the juxtaposition of softness mixed with the plot's challenging crime themes is an amusing dualism.  It is also funny that the jokes are thrown at the reader at a mile-a-minute pace alongside the action, which usually involves Sakamoto dealing with the day-to-day struggles of life like going to the grocery store is as severe as an assassination mission. After all, old habits die hard. However, despite its comedic tones, Sakamoto Days is for an older teen audience and features some violent scenes that should be avoided by the younger readers in the crowd. Luckily for our out-of-shape former criminal, he has a loving family that helps him keep on the straight and narrow. One of the best things about this manga is its main lead characters. Sakamoto's wife, Aoi, is his rock throughout and while she does know of his dark past, she sees the good in him and makes it her life's mission to guide her husband to be the best man he can be.  RELATED: The Best Free Short Manga on Manga Plus                 Love can change a man and Sakamoto Days reminds readers that even those who have the shadiest of histories can find redemption. So, instead of being a hitman for the Yakuza, Sakamoto utilizes his quick reflexes for customer care and community service, even if he gets carried away at times -- much to the chagrin of his wife and readers' amusement. As for some of the secondary characters in this manga, such as fellow former assassin-turned-convenience-store-clerk Shin, not many unique traits can be spoken for. Most of the side characters are, for lack of a better term, just there.  Sakamoto Days does not reinvent the wheel when it comes to comedy manga. The jokes are serviceable, complete with slapstick humor and visual gags that induce chuckles. The action scenes are well put together but will not blow readers' minds. But as a fun diversion with a somewhat retro aesthetic, Sakamoto Days does not need to be revolutionary to be entertaining and sets out to tell a silly story about redemption. It's the white cake of comedy manga: simple, somewhat sweet and direct. In a challenging world such as ours, sometimes folks need some comfort food -- even if it's all about crime and the bloodshed that comes with it. Home Anime My Dress-Up Darling: The Biggest Plot Twists in Season 1    My Dress-Up Darling: The Biggest Plot Twists in Season 1  By Louis Kemner Published 16 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Season 1 of My Dress-Up Darling took fans on a wild ride. Here's a look back at the anime's biggest plot twists so far.                 My Dress-Up Darling was a smash-hit rom-com anime in the Winter 2022 season, starring the lively cosplay enthusiast Kitagawa Marin and her new partner, the shy but hardworking Gojo Wakana. They soon embarked on an educational and uplifting journey into the world of cosplay together, and both gained a lot from it.  The story of My Dress-Up Darling is told in just 12 episodes, but it still managed to pack in some intriguing and meaningful plot twists and developments that kept the series moving at a healthy pace. Fans can look back fondly and remember the most impactful plot twists that helped the story and its characters along. RELATED: The Most Anticipated New & Returning Rom-Com Anime of Spring 2022          When Gojo Agreed to Make a Shizuka-Tan Cosplay For Marin                When Gojo and Marin first met early in My Dress-Up Darling, Marin made a request: for Gojo the doll maker to become her cosplay expert and help her make a costume of her favorite Slippery Girls 2 character, Shizuka-Tan. This request is what helped forge their new friendship, and Gojo accepted the challenge with relish.  The project helped establish their friendship, but also showed how devoted Gojo is to his craft. He amazed Marin when he pushed himself to finish her cosplay in record time, which helped set the tone for his character going forward. RELATED: How My Dress-Up Darling's Marin and Gojo Built Anime's Healthiest Friendship          When Gojo Called Marin Beautiful                After Gojo worked so hard on her cosplay, Marin went ahead and attended a cosplay event where everyone was getting their picture taken. On the train ride home, Gojo off-handedly remarked on Marin's beauty, since he, as a hina doll maker, equates it with quality and good craftsmanship. In his eyes, Marin was like a high-quality, living hina doll -- but Marin took it differently.  This was a love confession to her ears, and it changed the tone of their platonic friendship. Flattered, Marin developed an immediate and innocent crush on Gojo and maintained those feelings throughout the show, to the point of becoming jealously possessive. She even made the trademark yandere stare at one point, though no one was around to see it. RELATED: My Dress-Up Darling Embodies Horimiya's Best Storytelling Themes          When Gojo Combined His Two Hobbies To Improve His Skills                As My Dress-Up Darling continued, Gojo had to put his hina doll hobby on hold to make time for cosplay with Marin, and it was just as well. He had hit a wall with hina dolls after struggling to paint their faces correctly, but to his pleasant surprise, he learned that he could actually combine his hobbies.  By putting on Marin's cosplay makeup multiple times, Gojo became better at cosmetics, which meant he could paint hina doll faces better than ever. His hobbies had become more than the sum of their parts, boding well for his future with each hobby. Gojo's growth was quicker than many expected. RELATED: The My Dress-Up Darling Anime's Biggest Changes From the Manga          When Inui Sajuna Joined My Dress-Up Darling's Cast                Marin's cosplay role model and idol, the popular cosplayer Inui Sajuna, arrived to help Marin and Gojo take their hobby to the next level. In particular, she wanted Gojo to make a custom costume for her with his trademark quality. Along the way, Sajuna and her new friends learned much from one another.  Gojo and Marin both learned new strategies for costume creation and photography from Sajuna, while she in turn learned the value of homemade cosplay from Gojo and came to appreciate his expert technique. Having Sajuna was a distinct leap forward for Marin and Gojo's budding cosplay career together. RELATED: My Dress-Up Darling Celebrates Season Finale With New Artwork          When Inui Shinju Decided To Cosplay, Too                Sajuna's little sister Shinju was content to be her supporter and little more, with the latter lacking the confidence to try cosplay on her own. After meeting Gojo and Marin, however, Shinju finally worked up the courage to try her first cosplay, showing remarkable character growth. She amazed everyone in My Dress-Up Darling with her crossplay as a dark-haired male anime character, and is now a confident cosplayer who is ready to show off what she can do to the world. Home Anime An Introduction to Yu-Gi-Oh! Go Rush’s Card Game Mechanics for Old-School Fans    An Introduction to Yu-Gi-Oh! Go Rush’s Card Game Mechanics for Old-School Fans  By Gregory Segal Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   With Yu-Gi-Oh! Go Rush!! set to release this month, it seems like a better time than any to go over the game rules, as they're quite different!                 The gameplay of Yu-Gi-Oh! has changed throughout its many anime series and the physical card game. From the number of life points characters have to the summoning mechanics and type of monsters playable, each rendition of the show has developed and added a variety of new features.  Yu-Gi-Oh! Go Rush!! will be building on the rules that were introduced in its previous season, Yu-Gi-Oh! SEVENS, which saw the game take a dramatic turn from the formats that each previous anime has followed. Unlike the traditional game fans know and love, Rush Duels offers a more simplified game style, similar to Speed Duels, that harkens back to the old-school days of the game. Since Yu-Gi-Oh SEVENS has yet to be released outside of Japan, many fans may still be unfamiliar with the new mechanics of the upcoming show, so here’s a breakdown of what to expect. RELATED: Aharen-San's Premiere Episode Echoes Komi Can't Communicate's Shojo-Style Stor          What Changes To The Rules Have Been Made?                 The first thing that fans of the game will notice is that the duel field has been scaled down in size. Now, players only have three monster zones and spell and trap zones rather than the traditional five. Pendulum and Extra Monster zones no longer exist; however, this might be something that's developed within this new series. The mechanics for normal summoning monsters has also changed. Typically, characters have only been able to Normal Summon once per turn -- unless they’re cheating to enhance the plot, which can be seen pretty often in Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters. Yu-Gi-Oh! Rush Duels allows characters to Normal Summon or Set as many monsters as they want within a single turn; however, all Level 5 or higher monsters still must be Tribute Summoned.  To balance this mechanic, all monster effects can only be activated once per turn while they are face up on the field. Although this has an impact on how players play in real life, it's unlikely to dramatically alter how cards are used in the show. RELATED: How Naruto’s Backstory Is Similar to Orient Protagonist Musashi's As both the name of the series and the card game it is based upon suggest, the pace of duels is much quicker than fans have come to expect. This means that not only can characters summon monsters at a faster pace, but the number of cards that they draw has also increased. Rather than getting one card per turn during the Draw Phase, players are able to continuously add cards to their hand from the top of their deck until they have five cards. Moreover, there is no limit to the number of cards a character can have in their hand.  Since this occurs each turn and characters will lose a duel if they run through their deck too quickly, every game will likely be a rush to see who can win before this happens. Fans of the show can likely expect to see a few close games in which one character loses simply due to their inability to draw. Other slight tweaks to the game have been made, although the rest of the rules have largely remained the same. Characters start with 4000-8000 LP and can only have 40-60 cards in their Main Deck. However, there are other innovations present when it comes to the summoning mechanics of certain monsters.  RELATED: How Science Fell in Love Became a Battle Shonen Anime          How Does Fusion Summoning Work?                 Over the course of Yu-Gi-Oh’s history, fusion summoning has occurred in a plethora of different ways, from using the classic Polymerization card to unique Contact Fusions. Under the majority of circumstances, players are able to fuse monsters from their hands, field and sometimes even deck. However, in Yu-Gi-Oh! Rush!!, a fusion can only occur when monsters are on the player's field and the spell card “fusion” has been activated.          What’s Maximum Summoning?                 Maximum Summoning is a mechanic that's exclusive to Rush Duels and was first introduced in Yu-Gi-Oh! SEVENS. Characters initiate this summon by having all three pieces of a Maximum Monster in their hand and either an empty field or the ability to send all monsters they control to the grave.  RELATED: Sasaki and Miyano: How to Get Started With the Anime and Manga The monster summoned is treated as a single card and can only attack once unless it's otherwise stated. If the monster is destroyed or returned to the hand, the rest of the pieces follow suit. However, the effects of each card can be activated separately and summoned individually. Similar to Link Monsters, Maximum Monsters do not have any Defense and cannot be changed to Defense Position. As Yu-Gi-Oh! Go Rush!! progresses, it's possible that new mechanics and rules will come into play. When looking at its counterpart, Speed Duels, it's reasonable to assume that as time goes on, Synchro, Xyz, Pendulum and even Link Summoning will enter the game as characters discover new and exciting ways to duel each other. However, with space on the field being limited and Konami wanting to simplify the game for older fans of the show, it might be a while until this happens, if at all. Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home Anime Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original    Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original  By Angelo Delos Trinos Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Fans are often disappointed when live-action adaptations deviate from their favorite anime's storyline.                  Adapting an anime to live-action is incredibly tricky – anime and film are two completely different worlds. The best a live-action take can do is capture the spirit of the anime it's bringing to life, but a good number of movies fail in this regard.  RELATED: 5 Anime That Have A Great Live-Action Adaptions (& 5 That Fell Flat) Whether it's misunderstanding the anime's style and themes or deliberately going against everything the original stood for, these live-action adaptations fell short for reasons beyond being unfaithful to the visuals or lore.  10          Bleach Had None Of The Anime's Punk Energy                 For all its flaws, Bleach continues to be a beloved anime because of its punk aesthetic and energy. Whether it was the character designs, episodes' direction, or promotional material, Bleach had a uniquely colorful edge that most anime hope to have. Shinsuke Sato's adaptation, however, dropped all of these stylistic choices.  The live-action Bleach was an urban fantasy that grounded the anime's outlandish moments and world in serious realism. Outside some colorful title cards that disappeared after the first act, the movie had little in the way of anarchic energy. The movie is fairly decent and was even approved by Tite Kubo, but It's nowhere near as wild as it should've been.  9          The Gintama Movies Only Captured The Anime's Costumes & Looks                 Gintama earned its reputation as the gag anime to beat, but almost none of its mastery of humor and parody was reflected in its two live action movies, Gintama and Gintama 2: Rules Are Made To Be Broken. At most, the movies looked more like live-action recreations of the anime's most popular skits as performed by some impressive cosplayers.  Yuichi Fukuda's adaptations were at their best when they made up new jokes and spoofed the fact that they were movies, but these moments were few and far between. Gintama became what it is by making its own brand of comedy separate from the already hilarious manga, but, unfortunately, none of this originality was used for the movies.  8          Lupin The 3rd Had None Of The Anime's Spirit & Originality                 Lupin The Third isn't just a landmark anime, but it's practically an institution as well. The anime, manga's style, and story continue to influence Japanese fiction today, which is why any new adaptation should strive to break new ground as its forerunners did. Unfortunately, Ryuhei Kitamura's critically-panned Lupin The 3rd failed to do so.   RELATED: 5 Anime & Manga Couples That Honestly Shouldn't Be Together At most, all this adaptation had were some text-accurate costumes, poses, and quotes. The movie was as derivative as any uninspired con movie before it, complete with a needlessly convoluted plot that confused confusion for intrigue. By not even trying to do anything new, Lupin The 3rd was just a legendary anime's surface-level reenactment.  7          Kite Was Not As Controversial & Stylish As The OVAs                 Without exaggeration, the Kite OVAs are some of the most controversial anime ever created. Besides the excessive gore, Sawa's time as an assassin was borderline pornographic – so much so that the OVA was banned in certain countries. Understandably, the live-action adaptation toned these parts down or cut them, but lost the original's spirit in doing so.  Ralph Ziman's Kite was as forgettable and pedestrian as a movie about hitmen could get. Worse, it came out at the time when movies starring female assassins like Lucy or Salt were oversaturated. Kite's biggest flaw wasn't its lack of offensive content, but its refusal to be as audacious and stylish as its infamous anime by doing anything risqué.  6          Fist Of The North Star Lacked Its Source Material's Creativity & Scale                 At its heart, Fist Of The North Star is a martial arts-driven tale of revenge. That said, it more than made up for these familiar trappings by pushing everything to the extreme. Not only was the story set in the post-apocalypse, but Kenshiro was the latest master of the Hokuto Shinken style, which granted him the power to make enemies explode.  Few if any of the over-the-top aesthetics made it to the movie, which was as formulaic as a martial arts movie could get. Tony Randel's movie unwisely toned everything down, most egregiously seen in the fights that were nowhere near as bloody and exciting as their animated counterparts. At best, the sets were surprisingly well-made despite the low budget.  5          The Attack On Titan Two-Parter Was A Typical Zombie Apocalypse                 One of the many things that makes Attack On Titan the landmark it is today is that it bears one of the greatest bait-and-switch premises ever told. As it turns out, Paradis Island's war against the Titans wasn't the fight for humanity everyone thought it was, but a dark fate placed on an entire race of people that the world isolated and vilified.  The movies, however, were just another modern-day zombie apocalypse. In brief, the Titans were tall zombies born from failed weapons experiments, and they were stopped with a nuke. Whatever complexity the anime had (especially in themes of militarism, nationalism, racism, etc.) were simplified or dropped in Shinji Higuchi's B-grade two-parter.  4          City Hunter (1993) Was Just Another Jackie Chan Movie                 In the '90s, Jackie Chan became a star by headlining action-comedies about bumbling martial arts heroes who stumbled their way into larger conspiracies. City Hunter fit this bill perfectly, and therein lies the problem. If not for its source material's legacy, Wong Jing's adaptation would be indistinguishable from the likes of Mr. Nice Guy or Rumble In The Bronx.   All City Hunter got right were the characters' names and Ryo Saeba's comedic lechery. Though it had its moments, the movie was more of by-the-numbers Jackie Chan romp than an adaptation. Not helping matters is how City Hunter got the faithfully cartoonish adaptation it deserved in Philippe Lacheau's 2018 movie, which effectively supplanted Chan's.  3          Dragonball: Evolution Was A Highschool Adventure, Not A Galactic Epic                 Part of the reason why Dragon Ball is one of the most influential anime ever made is because of its seemingly bottomless depth of its world and Goku as a person. Goku wasn't just the Monkey King's parallel in this homage to the Chinese epic Journey To The West, he was also an intergalactic warrior, a loving father and friend, and the protector of Earth.  RELATED: Top 10 Worst Ways To Die In Dragon Ball For pragmatic and mostly cynical reasons, James Wong's Dragonball: Evolution scaled everything back. Here, Goku's quest for the Dragon Balls was a coming-of-age story that was more interested in his growth as a teen than the galaxy's defender. The movie didn't just lack the anime's grand scale, but also its stakes and development.  2          Ghost In The Shell Turned The Major Into A Generic Superhero                 Despite starring an iconic action star in Major Motoko Kusanagi, the original Ghost In The Shell was anything but a conventional action story. Instead, it was a meditation about the Major's existential and identity crisis in a technologically dominant world where she's both a cog in an unfeeling inhuman system and a mass-produced cyborg model.  In contrast, Rupert Sanders' movie was the Major's heroic origin story. Here, Major Mira Killian (a cyborg with the brain of the delinquent Motoko Kusanagi) was a one of a kind cyborg super-soldier who fought for justice. Even if it's watchable and momentarily ignoring the twist's racial implications, this movie was formulaic where the anime was anything but.  1          Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys Deconstructed Its Comedy                 In brief, Daigo Matsui's Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys is a deconstruction of the animated sitcom it was based on. The movie adapted some of the anime's most famous jokes and skits, but replaced the punchlines with depressing reality checks. Wacky situations ended with the boys getting reprimanded, or with them contemplating how stupid they acted. Home Anime Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original    Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original  By Angelo Delos Trinos Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Fans are often disappointed when live-action adaptations deviate from their favorite anime's storyline.                  Adapting an anime to live-action is incredibly tricky – anime and film are two completely different worlds. The best a live-action take can do is capture the spirit of the anime it's bringing to life, but a good number of movies fail in this regard.  RELATED: 5 Anime That Have A Great Live-Action Adaptions (& 5 That Fell Flat) Whether it's misunderstanding the anime's style and themes or deliberately going against everything the original stood for, these live-action adaptations fell short for reasons beyond being unfaithful to the visuals or lore.  10          Bleach Had None Of The Anime's Punk Energy                 For all its flaws, Bleach continues to be a beloved anime because of its punk aesthetic and energy. Whether it was the character designs, episodes' direction, or promotional material, Bleach had a uniquely colorful edge that most anime hope to have. Shinsuke Sato's adaptation, however, dropped all of these stylistic choices.  The live-action Bleach was an urban fantasy that grounded the anime's outlandish moments and world in serious realism. Outside some colorful title cards that disappeared after the first act, the movie had little in the way of anarchic energy. The movie is fairly decent and was even approved by Tite Kubo, but It's nowhere near as wild as it should've been.  9          The Gintama Movies Only Captured The Anime's Costumes & Looks                 Gintama earned its reputation as the gag anime to beat, but almost none of its mastery of humor and parody was reflected in its two live action movies, Gintama and Gintama 2: Rules Are Made To Be Broken. At most, the movies looked more like live-action recreations of the anime's most popular skits as performed by some impressive cosplayers.  Yuichi Fukuda's adaptations were at their best when they made up new jokes and spoofed the fact that they were movies, but these moments were few and far between. Gintama became what it is by making its own brand of comedy separate from the already hilarious manga, but, unfortunately, none of this originality was used for the movies.  8          Lupin The 3rd Had None Of The Anime's Spirit & Originality                 Lupin The Third isn't just a landmark anime, but it's practically an institution as well. The anime, manga's style, and story continue to influence Japanese fiction today, which is why any new adaptation should strive to break new ground as its forerunners did. Unfortunately, Ryuhei Kitamura's critically-panned Lupin The 3rd failed to do so.   RELATED: 5 Anime & Manga Couples That Honestly Shouldn't Be Together At most, all this adaptation had were some text-accurate costumes, poses, and quotes. The movie was as derivative as any uninspired con movie before it, complete with a needlessly convoluted plot that confused confusion for intrigue. By not even trying to do anything new, Lupin The 3rd was just a legendary anime's surface-level reenactment.  7          Kite Was Not As Controversial & Stylish As The OVAs                 Without exaggeration, the Kite OVAs are some of the most controversial anime ever created. Besides the excessive gore, Sawa's time as an assassin was borderline pornographic – so much so that the OVA was banned in certain countries. Understandably, the live-action adaptation toned these parts down or cut them, but lost the original's spirit in doing so.  Ralph Ziman's Kite was as forgettable and pedestrian as a movie about hitmen could get. Worse, it came out at the time when movies starring female assassins like Lucy or Salt were oversaturated. Kite's biggest flaw wasn't its lack of offensive content, but its refusal to be as audacious and stylish as its infamous anime by doing anything risqué.  6          Fist Of The North Star Lacked Its Source Material's Creativity & Scale                 At its heart, Fist Of The North Star is a martial arts-driven tale of revenge. That said, it more than made up for these familiar trappings by pushing everything to the extreme. Not only was the story set in the post-apocalypse, but Kenshiro was the latest master of the Hokuto Shinken style, which granted him the power to make enemies explode.  Few if any of the over-the-top aesthetics made it to the movie, which was as formulaic as a martial arts movie could get. Tony Randel's movie unwisely toned everything down, most egregiously seen in the fights that were nowhere near as bloody and exciting as their animated counterparts. At best, the sets were surprisingly well-made despite the low budget.  5          The Attack On Titan Two-Parter Was A Typical Zombie Apocalypse                 One of the many things that makes Attack On Titan the landmark it is today is that it bears one of the greatest bait-and-switch premises ever told. As it turns out, Paradis Island's war against the Titans wasn't the fight for humanity everyone thought it was, but a dark fate placed on an entire race of people that the world isolated and vilified.  The movies, however, were just another modern-day zombie apocalypse. In brief, the Titans were tall zombies born from failed weapons experiments, and they were stopped with a nuke. Whatever complexity the anime had (especially in themes of militarism, nationalism, racism, etc.) were simplified or dropped in Shinji Higuchi's B-grade two-parter.  4          City Hunter (1993) Was Just Another Jackie Chan Movie                 In the '90s, Jackie Chan became a star by headlining action-comedies about bumbling martial arts heroes who stumbled their way into larger conspiracies. City Hunter fit this bill perfectly, and therein lies the problem. If not for its source material's legacy, Wong Jing's adaptation would be indistinguishable from the likes of Mr. Nice Guy or Rumble In The Bronx.   All City Hunter got right were the characters' names and Ryo Saeba's comedic lechery. Though it had its moments, the movie was more of by-the-numbers Jackie Chan romp than an adaptation. Not helping matters is how City Hunter got the faithfully cartoonish adaptation it deserved in Philippe Lacheau's 2018 movie, which effectively supplanted Chan's.  3          Dragonball: Evolution Was A Highschool Adventure, Not A Galactic Epic                 Part of the reason why Dragon Ball is one of the most influential anime ever made is because of its seemingly bottomless depth of its world and Goku as a person. Goku wasn't just the Monkey King's parallel in this homage to the Chinese epic Journey To The West, he was also an intergalactic warrior, a loving father and friend, and the protector of Earth.  RELATED: Top 10 Worst Ways To Die In Dragon Ball For pragmatic and mostly cynical reasons, James Wong's Dragonball: Evolution scaled everything back. Here, Goku's quest for the Dragon Balls was a coming-of-age story that was more interested in his growth as a teen than the galaxy's defender. The movie didn't just lack the anime's grand scale, but also its stakes and development.  2          Ghost In The Shell Turned The Major Into A Generic Superhero                 Despite starring an iconic action star in Major Motoko Kusanagi, the original Ghost In The Shell was anything but a conventional action story. Instead, it was a meditation about the Major's existential and identity crisis in a technologically dominant world where she's both a cog in an unfeeling inhuman system and a mass-produced cyborg model.  In contrast, Rupert Sanders' movie was the Major's heroic origin story. Here, Major Mira Killian (a cyborg with the brain of the delinquent Motoko Kusanagi) was a one of a kind cyborg super-soldier who fought for justice. Even if it's watchable and momentarily ignoring the twist's racial implications, this movie was formulaic where the anime was anything but.  1          Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys Deconstructed Its Comedy                 In brief, Daigo Matsui's Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys is a deconstruction of the animated sitcom it was based on. The movie adapted some of the anime's most famous jokes and skits, but replaced the punchlines with depressing reality checks. Wacky situations ended with the boys getting reprimanded, or with them contemplating how stupid they acted.  Matsui did this because the manga and anime reminded him of his adolescence but, instead of nostalgia, he felt embarrassment and shame. His adaptation reflected his dour outlook, which undid everything that made the anime funny. Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys was one of the funniest shows of its time, and it deserved a movie better than this.                  10 Anime That Perfectly Balance Action & Comedy  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime bleach ghost in the shell ()     About The Author   Angelo Delos Trinos                                     (414 Articles Published)     CBR Staff Writer Angelo Delos Trinos' professional writing career may have only started a few years ago, but he's been writing and overthinking about anime, comics and movies for his whole life. Home TV TV News Doctor Who Reveals Spinoff Podcast Series Featuring the Thirteenth Doctor    Doctor Who Reveals Spinoff Podcast Series Featuring the Thirteenth Doctor  By Ben Wasserman Published 11 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The first-ever Doctor Who podcast story, Doctor Who Redacted, featuring Jodie Whittaker, announces its debut episode's release date and premise.                 Jodie Whittaker might only have a few Doctor Who episodes left before she regenerates, but the Thirteenth Doctor is about to receive even more adventures in podcast form.  The official Doctor Who website announced that Episode 1 of a ten-part podcast series called Doctor Who Redacted will drop on April 17, the same day as the 2022 special episode "Legend of the Sea Devils." Instead of being directly Doctor-centric, Redacted follows "three broke university drop-outs" and podcast co-hosts Cleo Proctor (Charlie Craggs), Abby McPhail (Lois Chimimba) and Shawna Thompson (Holly Quin-Ankrah), whose series "The Blue Box Files" analyzes the reoccurrence of a mysterious object (i.e. the Doctor's TARDIS) throughout historical records. However, Cleo, Abby and Shawna soon become the universe's best chance at survival, thanks ironically to poor viewership numbers, after getting "caught in a supernatural conspiracy as they learn that everyone who’s ever met the Doctor is disappearing and being forgotten."  RELATED: Is It Time for Doctor Who to Bring Back Its Oldest Companion? In addition to Whittaker as the Thirteenth Doctor, Craggs, Chimimba, and Quin-Ankrah's characters will meet some notable allies from past Doctor Who stories. These include UNIT Chief Scientific Officer Kate Stewart, scientist Petronella Osgood, Silurian Madame Vastra, and The Sarah Jane Adventures' Rani Chandra. Also joining the cast is Jacob Hawley as Cleo's brother Jordan, who is amongst those mysteriously "redacted" by the Doctor's newest foe. Whittaker debuted as the Thirteenth Doctor in 2018, becoming the first woman to portray the iconic Time Lord since Doctor Who began nearly sixty years ago. She's played the Doctor across three seasons, sharing a record with predecessors Peter Capaldi's and Matt Smith's Twelfth and Eleventh Doctors, respectively. However, instead of the modern Who's 13-episode series run, Whittaker's Doctor had two ten-episode series, followed by a six-part mini-seres Doctor Who Flux. The latest series saw the Doctor and longtime ally Yasmin Khan work together with multiple parties across space and time, including new companion Dan Lewis, to stop a threat from her past consuming the entire universe. Whittaker also voiced the Thirteenth Doctor in multiple video games, with the most recent one, Doctor Who: Edge of Reality, pairing her up with a returning David Tennant as the Tenth Doctor.  RELATED: Who Was The War Doctor in Doctor Who? "Legend of the Sea Devils" marks the titular reptilian Earth natives' return to Doctor Who for the first time since the Third Doctor era. The spring special will be followed up by Whittaker's final episode, for which the release date is not yet known. So far, no details have come out yet regarding the choice of Whittaker's replacement. It was rumored earlier this year that Hugh Grant was in consideration to play the Fourteenth Doctor, but the actor has since debunked that claim. Doctor Who Redacted will be available on BBC Sounds starting April 17. Home TV TV News Doctor Who Reveals Spinoff Podcast Series Featuring the Thirteenth Doctor    Doctor Who Reveals Spinoff Podcast Series Featuring the Thirteenth Doctor  By Ben Wasserman Published 11 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The first-ever Doctor Who podcast story, Doctor Who Redacted, featuring Jodie Whittaker, announces its debut episode's release date and premise.                 Jodie Whittaker might only have a few Doctor Who episodes left before she regenerates, but the Thirteenth Doctor is about to receive even more adventures in podcast form.  The official Doctor Who website announced that Episode 1 of a ten-part podcast series called Doctor Who Redacted will drop on April 17, the same day as the 2022 special episode "Legend of the Sea Devils." Instead of being directly Doctor-centric, Redacted follows "three broke university drop-outs" and podcast co-hosts Cleo Proctor (Charlie Craggs), Abby McPhail (Lois Chimimba) and Shawna Thompson (Holly Quin-Ankrah), whose series "The Blue Box Files" analyzes the reoccurrence of a mysterious object (i.e. the Doctor's TARDIS) throughout historical records. However, Cleo, Abby and Shawna soon become the universe's best chance at survival, thanks ironically to poor viewership numbers, after getting "caught in a supernatural conspiracy as they learn that everyone who’s ever met the Doctor is disappearing and being forgotten."  RELATED: Is It Time for Doctor Who to Bring Back Its Oldest Companion? In addition to Whittaker as the Thirteenth Doctor, Craggs, Chimimba, and Quin-Ankrah's characters will meet some notable allies from past Doctor Who stories. These include UNIT Chief Scientific Officer Kate Stewart, scientist Petronella Osgood, Silurian Madame Vastra, and The Sarah Jane Adventures' Rani Chandra. Also joining the cast is Jacob Hawley as Cleo's brother Jordan, who is amongst those mysteriously "redacted" by the Doctor's newest foe. Whittaker debuted as the Thirteenth Doctor in 2018, becoming the first woman to portray the iconic Time Lord since Doctor Who began nearly sixty years ago. She's played the Doctor across three seasons, sharing a record with predecessors Peter Capaldi's and Matt Smith's Twelfth and Eleventh Doctors, respectively. However, instead of the modern Who's 13-episode series run, Whittaker's Doctor had two ten-episode series, followed by a six-part mini-seres Doctor Who Flux. The latest series saw the Doctor and longtime ally Yasmin Khan work together with multiple parties across space and time, including new companion Dan Lewis, to stop a threat from her past consuming the entire universe. Whittaker also voiced the Thirteenth Doctor in multiple video games, with the most recent one, Doctor Who: Edge of Reality, pairing her up with a returning David Tennant as the Tenth Doctor.  RELATED: Who Was The War Doctor in Doctor Who? "Legend of the Sea Devils" marks the titular reptilian Earth natives' return to Doctor Who for the first time since the Third Doctor era. The spring special will be followed up by Whittaker's final episode, for which the release date is not yet known. So far, no details have come out yet regarding the choice of Whittaker's replacement. It was rumored earlier this year that Hugh Grant was in consideration to play the Fourteenth Doctor, but the actor has since debunked that claim. Doctor Who Redacted will be available on BBC Sounds starting April 17. Home Anime One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger - for an Unsurprising Reason    One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger - for an Unsurprising Reason  By Christian Markle Published 2 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Saitama is known for his lack of emotions in tense situations. In One-Punch Man Chapter 159, he surprisingly expresses immense anger.                  The following contains spoilers for One-Punch Man Chapter 159, "Source of Anxiety," by One, Yusuke Murata, John Werry and James Gaubatz, available in English at Viz Media.   Saitama is known for not being fazed by any threat or danger. He maintains a poker face, even in front of possible Earth-destroying catastrophe -- like when he fought Boros the alien invader or Monster King Orochi. However, that doesn't mean he is an unfeeling robot. There are some cases in which he is actually angered, but only in Chapter 159 has he reached the peak of hatred.  With the amount of power Saitama possesses, there's no longer anything that poses a threat to him. He simply decimates anything that stands in his way with a single punch, hence, the title of the manga. He is, however, not without weaknesses. He is often flustered for missing out on sales and is always problematizing his budget, and the Monster Association's wide-scale attack finally brought out the worst in him. RELATED:Every Giant-Centipede Monster in One-Punch Man (So Far) - and How They Died                 The first question Saitama asked the monsterized Garo was confirmation of his identity, which the Hero Hunter provided. He then launched into a long rant about being the absolute evil, but Saitama was no longer interested in what the monster had to say. Because he deemed Garo not to be a monster, despite the Hero Hunter's admittance, he was convinced there was nothing left for him to do there, leaving Garo surprised and confused..  Before leaving, though, Saitama ranted for a bit, recalling going out of his place to report the recurring noise. However, his house got destroyed, and he now had to go look for his belongings. Saitama expressed his frustration at the situation, claiming he was so angry he could destroy the world. Saitama's outburst wasn't just a bluff, because Garo felt immense pressure when the bald hero made the declaration. RELATED:One-Punch Man: The Hero Association's Strongest Fighter Begins a Godly Task                 Saitama getting angry is a rare occurrence, and this is the first time he reached a world-destroying level of anger. Unsurprisingly, the cause of his fury is not something heavy like losing a friend or witnessing great evil. Rather, it has something to do with his belongings. Saitama has always been concerned about things ordinary individuals will consider trivial -- like supermarket sales and winning against King in a video game. It is, however, interesting to see him express an emotion to that extreme.  Saitama has always been shown to be a calm-headed individual who couldn't feel any sense of danger, so seeing him in a fit of immense rage is a rare occurrence. If there's any moral lesson this teaches the audience, then it's that nobody should mess with Saitama's belongings under any circumstances. Home Anime Is Kiyo in Kyoto Entertainment or Education?    Is Kiyo in Kyoto Entertainment or Education?  By CBR Staff Published 3 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Kiyo in Kyoto is a show dedicated to teaching about Japanese culture, so can it also be entertaining?                 Kiyo in Kyoto: From the Maiko House is a lesser-known anime that came out at the tail end of the 2021 winter season. As it was produced by NHK World-Japan, the show walks a fine line between being just a means of entertainment and a means of education. There's only one way to find out whether it's more for entertainment or education, and that's by looking at the contents of the show.  However, before diving into the information given throughout the show, it's good to have an understanding of the context of Kiyo In Kyoto. The series follows Kiyo and her friend Sumire, who are both from Aomori Prefecture and want to become maiko (traditional Japanese entertainers found in Kyoto). While Sumire goes on to train and becomes a maiko, the titular character becomes the cook for that maiko house instead. The show then goes on to cover information about both maiko and Japanese food culture. As the show is produced by NHK World-Japan, the international version of the well-known Japanese broadcasting news and entertainment site, it would make sense that Kiyo in Kyoto is all about culture.  RELATED: Restaurant to Another World Vol. 1 Puts Iyashikei Into Isekai                 It's time to dive into the cultural aspects of the show, starting with the way it depicts the life of maiko. The series mainly takes place in the titular maiko house in the area of Kyoto called Kagai, where all the maiko and their housemothers live together. The show takes viewers along Sumire's journey in becoming a maiko, showing the training process with many tidbits of cultural information. It talks about the processes such as the classes maiko take to learn song and dance, as well as differences between maiko in training and maiko who have already made their "debut". One of these differences is the type of sash or obi the girls wear.  As seen in Episode 4, it shows how a senior apprentice who has not yet debuted wears a "half dangling sash," while a full maiko wears a longer "dangling sash." In that same episode, Sumire gets to debut as full-fledged maiko and gets her maiko name -- Momohana -- which they explain can be chosen in many ways. They can choose the Japanese characters for the maiko's name is by taking inspiration from their real names, from the maiko house they live in or even having it divined for them at a shrine. Along with all the information within the show, there is also a separate short video produced by NHK World-Japan called "Maiko [Maiko-san Chi no Makanai-san - Kiyo in Kyoto: From the Maiko House] - 3-minute Maiko," available on YouTube, where real-life maiko are showcased.  RELATED: How Assassination Classroom Offers a Glimpse at Japan's Educational System Another topic that's discussed a lot in Kiyo in Kyoto is food, which means there's also a lot of information and facts about food not only from Kyoto or Aomori but from all around Japan. The episodes are formatted around the food featured in their respective segment, as each episode is generally formatted into three parts, each a chapter of the manga featuring one main food. Then, after each segment, there are little "talking heads" segments, where Kiyo and Sumire, as well as sometimes their senior Tsurukoma, talk about the food they ate in that segment as well as their regional counterparts.  This segment is called "Sumire and Kiyo's Dish of the Day." A good example of the regional differences discussed during these scenes can be seen in the last segment of Episode 5, where the series talks about different soups from across Japan. It starts with the soup that was featured in the episode -- hittsumi soup from Aomori -- and goes on to talk about soups from other places, such as teppo soup from Hokkaido, natto soup from Yamagata and itoko soup from Kyoto. This kind of cultural analysis in these segments is common and very educational.                  Of course, to be an anime, the show must be entertaining as well, and entertaining it is. Kiyo in Kyoto has no lack of cute characters and scenes. Not everything in the show is meant to teach the viewer; it also contains a plot and characters that grow throughout, as well as numerous cute and fluffy scenes. The show can have both entertainment and educational elements within it, as many shows do. So, to answer whether Kiyo in Kyoto: From the Maiko House is an entertainment or an education series, it's happily both.                   Heaven's Design Team Mixes 'Edutainment' With... Home Anime Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?    Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?  By Louis Kemner Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   One specific character is the true boss of the Melromarc kingdom in The Rising of the Shield Hero - and an ally of Naofumi's.                 The Rising of the Shield Hero is a grim but exciting isekai anime starring the unfortunate protagonist Iwatani Naofumi, the titular shield-bearing hero who must save the Melromarc kingdom from Waves of monsters. At first it seemed no one in the royal court was on Naofumi's side, but that soon changed when the queen showed up.  Naofumi had a terrible experience with King Aultclay XXXII and his daughter, Princess Malty, but Queen Mirellia Melromarc is a different story. Her worldview and policies differ greatly from her scheming husband's, and she played a much bigger role in the later sequences of Season 1. This may continue well into Season 2 of Shield Hero as well. RELATED: Meet The Rising of the Shield Hero's Main Characters          The Fair Rule Of Queen Mirellia Melromarc                Shield Hero's Melromarc kingdom is a matrilineal nation, meaning the royal bloodline is carried through the women while men such as Aultclay marry into the family. This means Queen Mirellia wields the most power in Melromarc, but when Naofumi arrived with the other three Cardinal Heroes, she was nowhere to be seen. This led to a bad start for Naofumi's adventure, since King Aultclay and Princess Malty were scheming with the Church of Three Heroes to tarnish the Shield Hero's name forever. This scheme could have been uncovered and dealt with much sooner had the queen been there, since she is a fair and honorable ruler who doesn't share her husband and elder daughter's hatred of the Shield Hero.  There's more than a personal difference between the queen, king and elder princess, however. The three royals are split because of international and race politics as well, all based on the presence of demi-humans in the Melromarc kingdom and the historic role of the Shield Hero. In previous eras, the Shield Hero was a symbol of hope for the demi-humans, and in the modern era, Mirellia is also sympathetic to both parties rather than being prejudiced against anyone. This is why she accepted the tanuki-like Raphtalia as the Shield Hero's companion without complaint. Unlike the rest of the royal family, Mirellia -- and her younger daughter Melty -- seek to unite the four heroes and make use of the Shield Hero, rather than ostracize him because of race relations between humans and demi-humans. Queen Mirellia is a symbol of hope and tolerance in the eyes of demi-humans, which puts her at odds with her family and even the non-Shield heroes at times. But as Season 1 of Shield Hero showed, this all set her up as Naofumi's most powerful ally.  RELATED: How the Shield Hero Anime Refined the Isekai Harem Concept          How Queen Mirellia Aided Naofumi In Shield Hero Season 1                Queen Mirellia didn't appear at first in The Rising of the Shield Hero, but did make some cameo appearances along with her Shadow agents until being formally introduced later on. Mirellia helped uncover the Church of Three Heroes' plot with the king, and personally oversaw the trial where King Aultclay and Princess Malty were found guilty of conspiracy. Given Mirellia's influence and the quality of her investigation into the matter, this helped clear Naofumi's name beyond all about -- even the oafish Motoyasu was forced to recognize the Queen's words and turn against Malty. Mirellia was even prepared to execute the king and princess until Naofumi intervened and decided to punish them with humiliation and a loss of authority instead.  RELATED: Shield Hero: The Berserk-Style Power of Naofumi's Rage Shield Mirellia came to Naofumi's aid soon after the would-be "beach episode" at the Cal Mira archipelago, when an unexpected Wave arrived. Unlike the previous Waves, this would be a naval battle, and Mirellia personally led a small fleet of warships and soldiers to aid the four Cardinal Heroes in battle against a series of sea monsters. The queen proved her worth as a leader of men in that battle, commanding her fleet with a steady hand as the Cardinal Heroes took the lead against the Wave's strongest monsters.  The battle was a success, and Queen Mirellia will continue to aid Naofumi however she can against future Waves and other quests in Season 2. With a further authority to mobilize the other three Cardinal Heroes to help, Mirella is now poised to take center stage alongside Naofumi as Shield Hero continues. Home Anime How Dr. Stone Secretly Became Shonen's Batman    How Dr. Stone Secretly Became Shonen's Batman  By Louis Kemner Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Dr. Stone protagonist Ishigami Senku is a heroic investigator and inventor with surprising similarities to Batman.                 Dr. Stone is an edutainment anime series taking place in a far-future Stone Age where human civilization has long since rusted away, yielding to a primitive world of stone and the rule of the strong. Protagonist Ishigami Senku has other ideas, however. As a hopeful shonen hero, he's certain he can bring civilization back and usher in a better future.  Overall, Senku has little overlap with more traditional shonen heroes such as the rubbery pirate Luffy or even the sorcerer Itadori Yuji. Instead, Dr. Stone's lead is more like shonen's Batman -- without the gothic themes or personal angst. Senku is a merciful, resourceful and law-oriented hero who fights brutal villains with brains instead of brawn, making him worthy of any DC comic title. RELATED: How Science Fell in Love Became a Battle Shonen Anime          How Senku Built His Own Bat Family In Dr. Stone                Dr. Stone's Senku has many startling parallels with the Dark Knight, even if their personalities, settings and personal backstories differ greatly. In fact, not only is Senku a surprisingly accurate anime analog for Batman, he even has an entire Bat Family of his own: a group of trustworthy friends who all work together to help get the job done right.  To begin with, Senku recruited the curious "sorcerer" Chrome, who soon became his enthusiastic scientist apprentice similar to Batman taking on Jason Todd/Robin as his sidekick. Like Robin, Chrome is largely content to play second fiddle -- though he sometimes enjoys showing off his inventions, including re-creating 21st century devices without even realizing it. Senku then recruited his own Catwoman, the agile warrior/hunter Kohaku, who is personally loyal to him but also committed to her own cause. In this case, Kohaku has strong ties to her native Ishigami Village and her elder sister Ruri, the village priestess. Just the way Catwoman is sometimes Batman's ally and lover, Kohaku helps Senku whenever she can, though their relationship is largely platonic.  RELATED: Dr. Stone's Final Chapter Turns Senku Into Terminator's John Connor Senku, as the Stone Age Batman, also has his own Lucius Fox: the elderly craftsman Kaseki, who can build just about anything. Just the way Lucius helps Batman purchase or create new weapons and gadgets, Kaseki aids Senku by expertly crafting items such as glass flasks and thin strands of gold wire, and indeed, Senku wouldn't have gotten very far without him. Batman is an expert at using his tools, but not even he can invent everything himself. Finally, Senku gathered all these allies into his own bat cave -- his Kingdom of Science -- complete with its own flag. This secluded miniature kingdom was kept apart from Ishigami Village and Tsukasa's Empire of Might, which could each be considered Gotham City. By recruiting Chrome as his own Robin and Kohaku as Catwoman, Senku quickly built up his own bat family -- especially when Kaseki joined the crew and, later, the entirety of Ishigami Village. It wasn't easy though; Senku had to fight his own Bane more than once, such as the thuggish Magma and certainly Tsukasa, having to use his Batman-style wits and inventions to win the day without brute force or bloodshed. He and his "bat family" defeated Magma to make Senku the tribe's chief, and that in turn allowed Senku to administer medicine to the afflicted Ruri. The Stone Wars later began, and Senku reinvented walkie talkies and flash-bang grenades to compensate for his team's lack of strength against Tsukasa's own forces. Home Movies Movie Features How Tim Burton's Batman Beat Joker to a Major Origin Story Achievement    How Tim Burton's Batman Beat Joker to a Major Origin Story Achievement  By Robert Vaux Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   2019's Oscar-winning Joker received criticism for something Tim Burton did decades before in 1989's Batman: tell the Clown Prince's origin story.                 "If I have to have a past, then I prefer it to be multiple choice!" The Joker cackles in 1988’s The Killing Joke, the seminal comic written by Alan Moore, illustrated by Brian Bolland and colored by John Higgins. It’s a typically clever opt-out from Moore, who – tasked with creating a background story for Batman's greatest nemesis – ensured that his take couldn’t be considered definitive. It was part of what’s become a deliberately obtuse background for The Joker, whose true origins have yet to be definitively tracked down.  One of the criticisms levels against the 2019 movie Joker was precisely that it illuminated what had become so much fun to leave obscured. Some fans believed – not without justification – that the character didn’t need a backstory and that the tangle of varying explanations for how he came to be fit him like a glove. 2008’s The Dark Knight made direct reference to his slippery past, as Heath Ledger’s version of the character constantly changed the story of how he got the scars on his face. It was easy to forget that Tim Burton had already delivered a "definitive" origin three decades earlier with the original Batman and just one year after Moore’s indelible line.  RELATED: What Drives The Batman’s Joker to Laughter?                 Before The Killing Joke, the closest thing to an origin story in the comics came in Detective Comics #168 in 1951. It reveals the now-familiar story of The Red Hood Gang, whose leader wore a crimson bubble over his head. He fell into a vat of chemicals at the Ace Chemicals Plant during an attempted robbery broken up by the Batman, and while the hood’s protective features allowed him to survive, the chemicals turned his hair green and his skin white. He decided to abandon the Red Hood guise and adopt the identity of The Joker. Tim Burton used a similar version of that story in his 1989 movie. He simply did away with the notion of The Red Hood and made the Joker-to-be a mob lieutenant named Jack Napier. Batman arrives in the middle of a robbery attempt at Ace Chemicals and drops Napier into a vat – likely in revenge for the murder of his parents, whom Napier also killed – only to have the gangster re-emerge as the white-skinned Clown Prince of Crime. Jack Nicholson’s performance proved iconic, and the film introduced an entire generation of fans to both the Caped Crusader and his grinning archenemy. The origin story lingered, overlapping with Paul Dini’s Batman: The Animated Series among other properties and informing subsequent versions of the character on several occasions.  RELATED: The Batman’s Deleted Scene Makes Heath Ledger’s Iconic Joker Trait Even Scarier                 The Killing Joke didn’t so much change the origin story as give it a more tragic introduction. It depicts The Red Hood as a struggling stand-up comic who agrees to serve as the gang's figurehead during a crime to support his pregnant wife. As he prepares for the robbery, she and their unborn child are killed in a household accident. The criminals he’s associated with force him to go through the crime anyway, which is when Batman arrives. The guards shoot his accomplices, and he jumps into the chemicals to avoid the vigilante. When he emerges and discovers that his skin and hair have changed, the weight of events drives him completely insane.  That’s the version Joker cleaves most closely to, though it has its own take on the notion. Its protean Joker – named Arthur Fleck here – similarly fails as a comedian and struggles to make ends meet. He also possesses a neurological disorder that results in fits of uncontrollable laughter. He commits murder on a subway when a group of rich young rakes assaults him, then smothers his mother when he learns that she lied to him about his birth father. It takes the pathos of Moore’s figure – a normal man who had "one bad day" – and applies it to a realistic 1970s Gotham.  That’s enough to make it distinctive, which was the filmmakers' goal, but its gritty delivery of a very strong origin story was hardly the first. Burton delivered his Joker origin in a vastly different pop culture environment, and with two Oscar-winning retakes since then, the notion that either the ’89 Batman or Joker could "ruin" the character with a definitive origin is absurd. Without Burton, no other Batman movie could have happened, and if his Joker origin couldn’t stop alternates from cropping up, nothing will.
